item.title: "Father of Elder Scrolls" Julian LeFay Has Died
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Julian LeFay, widely regarded as "the father of The Elder Scrolls", has passed away at the age of 59, following what his studio described as a "courageous battle with cancer." His death was confirmed by OnceLost Games, the studio he co-founded, which called his passing "an immeasurable loss for our team, our community, and our industry."

According to CEO Ted Peterson, LeFay stepped away from work just a week before his death, choosing to spend his final days surrounded by family. Despite his illness, he remained actively involved in development, continuing to guide the team, mentor younger developers, and help shape The Wayward Realms to reflect his signature design philosophy and creative ambition.

Lefay was a key figure behind The Elder Scrolls: Arena and Daggerfall, two titles that laid the foundation for one of the most influential franchises in gaming history. His legacy was so deeply embedded in the series that the in-game deity Julianos was named in his honor. In 2019, LeFay teamed up with fellow former Bethesda developers Ted Peterson and Vijay Lakshman to establish OnceLost Games, announcing their ambitious new RPG, The Wayward Realms, in 2021.

OnceLost Games affirmed that work on the game will continue in LeFay's honor, stating that the team is dedicated to realizing the vision he helped build. "Julian's influence extends far beyond our studio," the statement reads. "He touched the lives of millions of players worldwide and inspired countless developers to push creative boundaries. His legacy will live on in every realm, quest, and moment of wonder players experience in The Wayward Realms."

The statement goes on to say that while "this is an immeasurable loss for our team, our community, and our industry," development on the game will continue. The team is committed to honoring LeFay’s legacy by bringing his vision to life.

The tribute concludes: "Julian's impact reaches far beyond our studio. He touched millions of players worldwide and inspired generations of developers to push creative boundaries. His legacy will live on in every realm, quest, and moment of wonder in The Wayward Realms."

item.title: Microsoft Confirms No $80 Xbox Games After All
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Microsoft announced earlier this year that it would begin charging $80 for some of its new games, including The Outer Worlds 2. However, that's no longer the case.

Obsidian has announced that The Outer Worlds 2 will launch at $70 for the standard edition. A spokesperson for Microsoft told IGN that none of its games will be $80 this holiday. To be sure, no game from Microsoft beyond The Outer Worlds 2 was announced with an $80 price point (though some theorized Black Ops 7 would be $80), but in any event, Microsoft won't charge that much for any title this year.

"We're focused on bringing players incredible worlds to explore, and will keep our full priced holiday releases, including The Outer Worlds 2, at $69.99--in line with current market conditions," the spokesperson said.

As for press time, the Xbox.com page for The Outer Worlds 2 still shows an $80 price point for the standard edition and $100 for the premium edition.

Anyone who preordered The Outer Worlds 2 for $80 can get a refund or reimbursement from the story they ordered from.

When Microsoft announced $80 games, the company said the decision to charge more was made "with careful consideration given market conditions and the rising cost of development."

With The Outer Worlds 2 no longer retailing for $80, that makes Nintendo's Mario Kart World the only major new release from a big publisher going for $80 this year.

item.title: Borderlands 4 On Switch 2 Will Run "Mostly" At 30FPS, Will Also Support Joy-Con Mouse Controls
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Following the confirmation that Borderlands 4 will launch on October 3 for Switch 2, Gearbox boss Randy Pitchford has revealed a few more details about this version of the game. Responding to fans online, Pitchford said that Gearbox is aiming for the game to run at 30fps on Switch 2, but "intense" moments will see dips in performance. Pitchford also briefly confirmed that Borderlands 4 will support the Joy-Con 2's mouse mode.

"It was important to us to not cut anything and to support cross-play with other platforms," Pitchford explained. "It'll be mostly around 30fps, with some dips in some intense moments [of] heavy combats or if hosting a multiplayer game in handheld mode, etc."

Anyone looking to buy a physical copy of Borderlands 4 for Switch 2 will also have to clear some space on the console, as Pitchford suggested that it might be sold as a Game-Key Card. "It's a big game. There will be a download, even for physical copies," Pitchford wrote.

Game-Key Cards essentially turn the Switch 2 cartridge into an authentication key to enable the download of the game directly to the console. It's worth noting that Game-Key Cards aren't tied to your Nintendo account, as they can be used be shared with friends or sold to another person.

Borderlands 4 will also be available for PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S, and the game will launch earlier for those platforms on September 12. As its release date draws closer, Gearbox has begun sharing more details on the game's playable characters--like the new Siren named Vex--the hundreds of collectibles that you probably won't find, and an option to finally make Claptrap shut up.
